articles.title: Capital hosts international climate conference
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Two-day international conference on climate change will kick off in the capital on Thursday. Around 100 international experts will gather at the conference being held under the 'Breathe Pakistan' initiative of Dawn Media group in partnership with United Nations Pakistan. The event will lead to shaping a sustainable future to make Pakistan climate-resilient by 2047.

articles.title: Officials work to protect beaches from shore damage in Georgetown County
articles.author: Dalilah James
articles.summary: Georgetown County held a council retreat to discuss current and future issues. They are working with Georgetown County on developing a long-term beach management plan. The Litchfield and Garden Beach shorelines were nearly destroyed during Tropical Storm Debby. Every year, the beaches in the county lose nearly 200,000 cubic yards of sand.

articles.title: Agrarian Policy in India Confronting climate change for a sustainable future
articles.author: Daily Excelsior
articles.summary: By 2050, India will have to feed about 1.7 billion people. Climate change may reduce agricultural productivity by 10-20% by 2050. Research and development must be invested in developing diverse crop varieties that will be able to suit the ever-changing climatic conditions. The Green Revolution model has been too obsessed with short-term gains in productivity and has short-changed the sustainability of agricultural practices.

articles.title: How India has signalled a shift in the way it views climate crisis
articles.author: Financial Express
articles.summary: In the last year or so, India has signalled a subtle but important shift in the way it views the climate crisis and how it wants to deal with it. India has questioned the excessive preoccupation of the international community with climate change.

articles.title: US May Be Frigid, but the World Is Still Sweating
articles.author: Newser Editors
articles.summary: The world warmed to another monthly heat record in January. January was 0.09 degrees Celsius (0.16 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than January 2024, the previous hottest January. It was the 18th month of the last 19 that the world hit or passed the internationally agreed-upon warming limit of 1.5 C above preindustrial times.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice at second-lowest level ever recorded, scientists caution it's a size of 60 times Wales.
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice extent is down 498,000 square miles (1.29 million square kilometres) compared to the 1981 to 2010 average. The Arctic is missing an area six times the size of Wales. Warm temperatures have prevented ice from forming properly over the winter. Since 1979, the Arctic has lost 726,000 sq miles of sea ice, which is the same size as Alaska.

articles.title: SCIENCE SNIPPET: 'False Spring' South Texas warmth to continue?
articles.author: Zuleika Soler
articles.summary: Temperatures in Corpus Christi, Texas have been above normal and near record high this week. La Niña is expected to potentially last through April. For the next three months much of the south will likely experience above normal temperatures. Next week's cold front will bring the temperatures back to seasonal.

articles.title: It's Official: January Was The Warmest On Record
articles.author: Un News
articles.summary: Last month was 1.75 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial level and 0.79°C above the 1991-2020 average. January 2025 will be remembered by 'wetter-than-average conditions' over western Europe, as well as parts of Italy, Scandinavia and the Baltic countries. It was wetter than average in Alaska, Canada, central and eastern Russia, eastern Australia, southeastern Africa, and southern Brazil.

articles.title: Flock together for the Great Backyard Bird Count
articles.author: Kellen M. Quigley

They reported 7,920 species of birds from 200-plus countries and subregions. CCE Cattaraugus County is encouraging all residents to join the count.

articles.title: Kiawah officials work to determine 2025 priorities
articles.author: Meredith Blair

The planning commission is working to update the town's comprehensive plan and the council's strategic planning will go hand-in-hand with that. The non-finalized comprehensive plan can be viewed here and residents can submit comments to the public comment portal.

articles.title: Record January warmth puzzles climate scientists

articles.summary: Last month was the world's warmest January on record, according to the UNICEF data.    -1.8 degrees Celsius was the warmest on record for the whole of January.  -2.7 degrees Celsius is considered the average for January.

articles.title: Record January warmth puzzles climate scientists
articles.author: Qatar tribune
articles.summary: Last month was the world's warmest January on record raising further questions about the pace of climate change. January 2025 ended up 1.75C warmer than January temperatures of the late 19th Century, before humans started significantly warming the climate. The world's warming is due to emissions of planet-heating gases from human activities.

articles.title: Escalating Heat Episodes Signal One-Third Of Earth To Become 'Unsurvivable' After 2050
articles.author: Kiran N. Kumar
articles.summary: King's College London warns that exceeding the 2°C warming threshold above pre-industrial levels could render vast portions of the planet uninhabitable due to extreme heat stress. Extreme heat events have already claimed more than 260,000 lives since 2000, highlighting the immediate threat posed by rising temperatures.

articles.title: This year's Jan warmest on record globally in 175 yrs: EU's climate agency
articles.author: Gaurav.Talwar
articles.summary: Dehradun: January was the warmest January on record globally since 1850, with surface air temperatures 1.75°C above pre-industrial levels. This comes after 2024 was recorded as Earth's hottest year, when global average temperatures surpassed 1.5°C for the first time. January 2025 is another surprising month, continuing the record temperatures observed over the past two years, despite the development of La Nina conditions in the tropical Pacific. Arctic sea ice reached its lowest extent for Jan last month. Antarctic sea ice was 5% below average. Sea surface temperatures (SSTs) remained unusually high across many parts of the world. The report also detailed shifting weather conditions across the

articles.title: Long Overdue Freezing of the Arctic Circle – [your]NEWS
articles.author: Penny Carter
articles.summary: Verkhoyansk, a town in the Arctic Circle of Russia, holds the record for highest temperature in Arctic Circle at 100.4°F in 2020 and the lowest temperature ever recorded in Arctic circle at -90°F well over 100 years ago. The study conducted by World Weather Attribution has collected evidence pointing to human activity being responsible for the late freezing over of the Siberian Ocean.

articles.title: Remote parts of Western Australia brace for near 50C temperatures
articles.author: Charlie McLean
articles.summary: Residents in Western Australia's remote north west are expecting little relief from sweltering conditions with temperatures in the high 40s stretching into the weekend. Gascoyne Junction, 940 kilometres north of Perth, came close to equalling a 65-year national record of three consecutive days above 49C this week. Meteorologist Bob Tarr says it's unusual for such extreme temperatures to persist for so long. Mine workers in Newman are on high alert for intense storms that follow heatwaves.

articles.title: Fighting global warming in nations' self-interest: UN climate chief
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Simon Stiell is the UN's climate chief. He spoke at a university in Brazil's capital on Thursday. He said global heating was "dangerously high" but real progress had been made since the Paris Agreement. The United States is withdrawing from its leadership role in the fight against global warming.

articles.title: Fighting global warming in nations' self-interest: UN climate chief
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Simon Stiell is the UN's climate chief. He spoke at a university in Brazil's capital on Thursday. He is seeking to shore up solidarity on combating global warming as the U.S. retreats from its leadership role in the fight against climate change.

articles.title: 2025 Kicks Off With Warmest January on Record
articles.author: Paige Bennett
articles.summary: January 2025 was the warmest January on record, according to data from the EU Copernicus Climate Change Service. January 2025 was 1.75 degrees Celsius warmer than average January temperatures from pre-industrial times. An El Niño event that lasted from summer 2023 well into spring 2024 exacerbated higher temperatures in 2024. With a cooling La Niña starting up in early 2025, scientists have been left surprised by the record-high air temperature for January 2025.

articles.title: Climate Change Could Erase $1.47 Trillion in Property Values by 2055, Study Says
articles.author: Snejana Farberov
articles.summary: By 2055, climate change is projected to erase $1.47 trillion in U.S. home values and cause the displacement of tens of millions of people in the next 30 years. articles.title: Haiti
articles.author: In Sight Crime
articles.summary: Haiti is one of the 16 sovereign countries in the Caribbean region. It occupies the western third of the island of Hispaniola, which it shares with the Dominican Republic to its east, Cuba and Jamaica to its west, and the Bahamas to its north. The country's porous maritime and land borders make it an ideal transit point for drugs. Haiti's location makes it vulnerable to hurricanes and earthquakes. Haiti was a French colony in the 18th century, it revolted in 1791, it declared its independence from France in 1804, and it was occupied by US forces from 1915 to 1934. Jean-Claude Duvalier ruled Haiti as a brutal dictatorship from 1957 to 1986.

articles.title: Focus Edition: Exploring the Cryosphere
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Special Issue of Science spotlights critical insights into the Arctic and Antarctic. Climate change is reshaping these landscapes and presenting formidable geopolitical challenges for ongoing research efforts. Global temperatures are projected to soar 2.7°C above preindustrial levels. Greenland's melt zones could expand by four times and permafrost might diminish by 50%. The biodiversity in the Antarctic remains an enigma.

articles.title: Anambra Interfaces With NIMET, Develops Plans For A Flood-Free State

articles.title: The Globe Just Experienced Its Warmest January On Record, Despite Much Of The US In The Deep Freeze

January 2025 was 3.15 degrees Fahrenheit (1.75 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial levels. It was the 18th month of the last 19 in which the average temperature globally was above the 2.7 degrees threshold set by the Paris Climate Agreement.

articles.title: NZ escapes hottest January on record, but warmer weather coming

articles.summary: Palos Verdes Peninsula in Southern California is experiencing a slow-moving landslide averaging 4 inches per week between Sept. 18 and Oct. 17, 2024. The landslide both expanded and accelerated last summer, drawing attention to a populated region that historically had not been moving. The region has been a big focus for scientific research due to the prominent landslide threat. NASA's upcoming Landslide Climate Change Experiment will use airborne radar to study how extreme wet or dry precipitation patterns influence landslides.

articles.title: January 2025: Warmest Month on Global Record

The average temperature over European land for January 2025 was 1.80°C, 2.51°C above the 1991-2020 average for January. The sea surface temperature was 20.78°C over 60°S–60°N, the second-highest value on record for the month, 0.19°C below the January 2024 record. January 2025 saw predominantly wetter-than-average conditions over regions of western Europe, as well as parts of Italy, Scandinavia, and parts of Scandinavia. Heavy precipitation led to flooding in some regions.

articles.title: Cutting pollution to prevent climate change has accelerated climate change: report

articles.summary: This past January was the warmest on record, according to former NASA scientist James Hansen. This is due to humans cutting down on the amount of pollution in the air, which has made the earth warmer. The UN's goals on climate change appear to be impossible to achieve unless some miracle occurs.

articles.title: Watch the economy dry up if we just abandon the environment
articles.author: Patrick O'Connor
articles.summary: Even if your motives are purely economic, there are compelling reasons for Australia to lift its game in the management of the environment. The majority of our economy is heavily dependent on nature and the valuable services that are provided by a functioning environment. It's time to lift the game.

James Hansen and his co-authors say the Earth is more sensitive to warming from the emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs) than earlier believed and the '2 degrees Celsius goal is dead'. The rise in sea levels, compounded by melting glaciers, has caused significant coastal erosion. The rapid urbanisation and construction have worsened flooding. The city lacks a proper sewage and drainage system.

The conference highlights innovative solutions for the challenges related to water and food security arising from climate change. It is organized in response to the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including Goal 2 that entails ending hunger and Goal 6 which declares importance of achieving clean water and sanitation for all.

Sunday's high is expected to be 3°C, with an overnight low of -2°C in Victoria. Next week will be mostly sunny, but overnight lows are expected to get as low as -6°C early next week.

This is despite 2024 being registered as the world's hottest on record. The biggest driving factor for this record temperature is greenhouse gas build-up from the burning of fossil fuels. Donald Trump declared a national energy emergency within days of his inauguration.
